results.title: Fishery in Japan
results.brief_description: Fish plays a large part in the diet of the Japanese people, providing them with much needed protein. It is eaten in various forms, some of which are a delight to the eye as well as the palate. Japan has one of the world’s largest and most efficient fishing industries, all types of fishing operations, coastal and deep-sea, canning and freezing operations are shown.

results.title: Fishermen of Pubnico
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Victor Jobin and Leonard Forest
results.brief_description: A film story about the people who live in the nine fishing villages of Pubnico on the southwest tip of the Nova Scotian peninsula. Like that of their Acadian ancestors, their livelihood is inextricably bound to the sea. Characteristic of their faith in its bounty is the quest of the captain of a fishing schooner who, after a fruitless three-week search for swordfish, borrows money and sets out again. Eight more days of scanning the waves are rewarded by a full catch and money in the pocket for the captain and his crew.

results.title: Fishermen
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB and Guy L. Cote
results.brief_description: Should he choose to stay boss of his own boat and hope for better catches, or seek a job in commercial fishing, trading independence for a more certain income? This film is about the choice that faces many of Canada’s east-coast fishermen. (Awards: Berlin; Bloemfontein; Columbus)

results.title: Fisherman's gamble
results.brief_description: A sea hunt for swordfish off the Nova Scotia coast. A swordfish is more like a torpedo than a fish and, with five feet of boat-piercing armour for a nose, it is almost as deadly. Catching one is an exciting test of strength, with some anxious moments.

results.title: Fisherman's fall
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Peter Jones and Robert Nichol
results.brief_description: One of Canada’s best known fly-fishermen, essayist Roderick Haig-Brown, demonstrates the art of salmon fishing in the Campbell River of northern Vancouver Island. The film, like the fisherman, has eyes for more than the river’s surface. The camera looks below, showing what the fish sees and the fisherman senses. A film of solitude and of harmony with nature. (Awards: Toronto; Detroit; Novi Sad)

results.title: Fisheries in Japan
results.creator_credit: Iwanami and E F V A
results.brief_description: Provides an aerial view of the islands of Japan and shows the main ocean currents and the types of fish found in them. Describes various methods of fishing and studies salmon hatcheries in some detail. Re-edited by the Education Foundation for Visual Aids (UK).

results.title: Fish: the food with a catch to it
results.brief_description: Overview of the scope of the fishing industry: identifies the world’s leading fishing nations and illustrates the immense variety of fish caught. Traditional and modern methods of locating, catching, processing and preserving seafoods are shown. Also investigates the expanding activity in aquaculture or “fish farming”.

results.title: Fish: animal classes
results.brief_description: Learn all about fish in an entertaining way. This video explains that fish are the oldest vertebrate class on earth and that there are more than 24,000 species of them. It also describes the three categories of fish (primitive, bony and cartilaginous), as well as the anatomy of all fish including: gills, fins, skin and scales, cold- and warm-blooded types, swim bladders and lateral lines. Live-action footage illustrates the incredible variety and drama of life underwater. Also described are the little-known that ways in which fish smell, taste, see and hear. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.

results.title: Fish spoilage control
results.brief_description: An animated cartoon illustrating bacteriological contamination of fish and correct methods of handling to ensure freshness from boat to dinner table. The spoilage process is portrayed by battalions of little red demons, who march in full invading force upon the hapless forms of freshly caught fish. They demonstrate effectively how every act of carelessness in fish handling will increase their numbers, and also how proper refrigeration and sanitary handling will rout them.

results.title: Fish in farm dams
results.creator_credit: New South Wales Film Corporation and John Gacy
results.brief_description: Shows aspects of the native warm water fish breeding program being carried out at the Island Fisheries Research Station, Narrandera, NSW. Also looks at the work being done by State Fisheries and the Water Resources Commission which benefits farmers.
